1. Mahatma Gandhi – The Story Of My Experiments With The Truth If you want to know all about Gandhi and his journey, you cannot miss out on reading ‘My Experiments with the Truth’, his autobiography that covers his life from early childhood till 1921. The introduction mentions how Gandhi resumed writing at the insistence of a fellow prisoner at Yerwada Central jail. The autobiography was written as weekly journals and then compiled and published as a book. From his childhood memories, his experiments with eating meat, smoking, drinking and stealing to the demise of his father, the book captures many unknown instances of Gandhi’s life.  2. R.K. Narayan – The GuideR.K Narayan is best known for stories based in and around the fictional village of Malgudi. The Guide is yet another story set up in Malgudi. R.K. Narayan won the Sahitya Akademi Award for the book in 1960. The Guide is the story of a tour guide who transforms himself into a spiritual Guru and then the greatest holy man of India. The book was also adapted as a film which starred the legendary actor Dev Anand.  3. Rohinton Mistry – A Fine BalanceThis is the second novel by Mistry published in 1995 and, like his first novel, Such A Long Journey, this novel too received wide acclaim across the globe. A fine balance revolves around various characters in Mumbai (then Bombay) during the time of turmoil and government emergencies. The story of friendship and love that progresses among the characters of the book will keep you hooked till the end.   4. Salman Rushdie – Midnight’s ChildrenMidnight’s Children portrays the journey of India from British rule to independence and then partition. The book received a great response, winning the Booker Prize in 1981 and the “Booker of Bookers” Prize (commemorating the best among all the Booker winners) twice – in 1993 and 2008! The book travels to various parts of the country including Kashmir, Agra and Mumbai and incorporates many actual historic events. The book was also included in the List of 100 Best Novels of all time. 5. Jhumpa Lahiri – The Interpreter Of MaladiesThis is a collection of nine stories by Lahiri. The stories are based on lives of Indians and Indian Americans who are lost between the two cultures. The book was published in 1999 and won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction and the Hemingway Foundation/PEN Award in the year 2000 and has sold over 15 million copies worldwide.  You can read the complete list of 20 books here- http://www.thebetterindia.com/11594/20-gems-indian-literature-must-read/

Sadly, many of the novels that you should be reading are written in vernacular languages. The translations of these works is most of the time pathetic or at best slightly readable. I will start with colonial writings so that you can get an understanding of how British saw India. Works of Rudyrad KiplingTake up the White man’s burden —Send forth the best ye breed —Go bind your sons to exileTo serve your captives’ need;To wait in heavy harnessOn fluttered folk and wild —Your new-caught, sullen peoples,Half devil and half child. Kim (1900): This is the story about an Irish vagabond orphan who is taken up by the British secret service and conscripted into the Great Game of repelling Russian influence in the Himalayas. Kim is a book weaving together Buddhism and espionage, the colourful life of the bazaar and the Grand Trunk Road. 2. Up The Country (1876)by Emily Eden Emily Eden was the sister of George Auckland, Governor General.Her travels across northern India provide a seemingly innocent and remarkably acute commentary on life at the top but also a contrite record of her brother’s disastrous policy in Afghanistan. 3. Curry and Rice(1860) by George Francklin Atkinson Captain Atkinson describes with a delicious wry touch the ramshackle routine in the backwoods of British India in the 1850s: the innocent young subaltern, the disillusioned old major with his Indian family, the mangy pack of hounds they hunt with and the even mangier cattle in the bazaar, the cigar-chomping padre, and the servants fussing around their sweating masters. 4. Writings of Jim Corbett (very essential) The legendary Jim Corbett became famous first for killing the man-eating leopards and tigers who were preying on villagers in the hills of northern India. Later on became equally famous for his efforts to conserve their habitat and the national tiger reserve is today called Jim Corbett Park. This enthralling account of big-game hunting can safely be enjoyed because it is about taking life only in order to preserve it. 5. Anand Math by Bankim Chandra 6.Autobiography of an Unknown Indian by Nirad Choudhari 7. The Necklace of Kali by Robert Towers For a refreshing perspective on colonial India—that of a U.S. State Department officer in the last days of Raj .Consulate Visa Officer John Wickham is part of what is called the "Jungly Wallah" set: "a shifting population of rich Indians, Persians, Armenians, poor but ingenious White Russians . . . and assorted American and Britons," who take their name from the club they all frequent. Wickham is a complicated, principled man, whose dealings with people from all strata of society mirror the uneasiness of a country on the cusp of a bloody independence. 8. Sea Of Poppies trilogy and The Glass Palace by Amitav Ghosh The intergenerational novel about a Burmese boy falling in love with an Indian girl spans over half a century, beginning with the British Invasion of Burma in 1885 all the way to Indian independence in 1947. Extensively-researched and teeming with detail, The Glass Palace portrays both the decline of royalty and the rise of Industrial trade in a surprisingly personal manner. 9. Writings of M.M.Kaye The Sun In The Morning Golden Afternoon Shadow Of The Moon 10. John Masters work such as The Deceivers Now moving on to some recent works 1.A Fine Balance and other works by Rohinton Mistry A Fine Balance tells the story of two Bombay tailors who struggle to stay afloat during the tumultuous infighting of the 1970’s. 2. Inheritance Of Loss by Kiran Desai A retired Himalayan judge’s family trying to hold his family together during the Nepalese uprising is the main theme of the novel. The Inheritance of Loss explores the consequences of colonialism and present-day globalisation upon a once-isolated pastoral life. 3. A Suitable Boy by Vikram Seth 4. All the writings of R.K.Narayan 5. Shantaram by Gregory Roberts 6. Saraswati Park by Anjali Joseph It explores what it is like to be homosexual in India, which is still a largely taboo subject in our country. The story follows a sexually uncertain 19-year-old student growing up in Mumbai, who has a relationship with a boy at college. 7. The White Tiger by Aravind Adiga 8. Twilight in Delhi by Ahmed Ali Written in 1940, this novel looks back to Delhi in the 1910s, drawing a vivid picture of Muslims living in old Delhi during that era. The novel charts the downfalls of Mughal emperors and the colonial effects on Indian Muslims living in the country’s capital. 9.What The Body Remembers by Shauna Singh Baldwin Set in the run-up to Indian partition, Singh Baldwin’s debut novel follows the fate of two women married to the same man. Impoverished girl Roop is pleased to learn she is to become the second wife of a wealthy Sikh landowner and hopes she can become friends with his older wife, Satya. Their relationship turns out to be far more complex than she had thought. 10. Vaikom Bashir’s work (highly recommended) 11. Khushwant Singh 12. Ponnayen Selvan by Kalki This is a series about the Imperial Cholas. Highly recommended though the translations are a hinderance and the beauty of the work is lost. 13. Munshi Premchand , a must read author 14. One Part Woman by Perumal Murgan 15. Hangwoman by KR Meera

1) Midnight's Children by Salman Rushdie: A "Booker of the Booker" prize winning book by India's most controversial author. A magnificent piece of work describing India's transition from a colony to an independent nation and its journey henceforward. One of the best Historical Fiction ever written.  2) A House for Mr. Biswas by V.S Naipaul: The most memorable book by a Nobel prize winner deserves a place in this list. It is seldom that the book's central character goes suffers tribulations like Mohun Biswasand the author is capable of "not adapting" a serious tone. Even the central character's death was unable to bring in an ounce of sympathy in this comic masterpiece . And it gets increasingly tough if the character is based on your own father. V. S. Naipaul's restraint is what makes him one of the Grand Daddies of English Literature and this novel one of the greatest novels erver written.  3) God of Small Things by Arundhati Roy: Small things affect and change people, shaping them into what they are and how they behave. The book revolves around this central theme is truly one of the most insightful book on why someone behaves the way he/she does.  4) The Hungry Tide by Amitav Ghosh: Amitav Ghosh's ability to delineate a distant, secluded and an often forlorn culture/land is on a level of its own. "The Hungry Tide" is the epitome of this genius.Though a trite story its complex characters with a totally contrasting set of ethics and goals,  evocative narratives set across in the wild, dangerous and beautiful Sundarbans ensures that it has all the ingredients  for being a page-turner. It provides some great insights into the life of the locals and certain discernment of how your surroundings will affect your moral boundary that tells you of right and wrong.  5) The Great Indian Novel by Shashi Tharoor: When a coveted Political Science intellectual decides that he is going to write a political satire the story of one of the most influential, tumultuous, enthralling and massive political movement (Indian Independence Struggle) in history of world and recast into the country's greatest epic, The Mahabharata, it really does not get better than that. Sprinkled with clever puns through out it is a must read for anyone with political or historical leanings.  Honourable mentions:1)A Suitable Boy by Vikram Seth (Easily as good as any of the above)2)The Company of Women by Khushwant Singh3)5 Point Someone by Chetan Bhagat: I understand that this author is usually derided for his skill with the pen and most of his Novels are not exactly masterpieces but this one was a page-turner. His style was fresh, the characters interesting and the story was exciting. Sources: Wikipedia

Serious Men by Manu Joseph.one of the books i love. Summary Serious Men starts off with Ayyan Mani, who is a Tamil Dalit, residing in the Worli chawls of Mumbai. Ayyan works at the Institute of Theory and Research as a personal assistant. His responsibility is to answer private phone calls and read confidential letters. Acharya is the head astronomer at the institute, and spends a great deal of time researching the actual reason behind the Universe, exploring the possibility of extraterrestrial life. Ayyan’s only desire is to bring joy to the lives of his wife and their ten year old son. He then begins to spin the yarn that his son, who is partially deaf, is a genius, which captivates nearly the entire nation.Acharya’s belief is that the Big Bang Theory is a proposition about the Universe’s existence by the West. He argues that the Vatican wanted to have some sort of plot that staged the creation of the Universe and the Big Bang Theory is the ideal one they chose. He goes on to explain his proposition, which is that the Universe could be a giant device that is capable of manufacturing pieces of life. Acharya gears himself towards launching a balloon into outer space, as he believes that these pieces may be floating around in the upper atmosphere.The time comes when Acharya meets with a young astrobiologist named Oparna Goshmaulik, who poses a threat to Acharya’s reputation and the myth surrounding Ayyan’s son. While extremely good at her work, Oparna plays the role of a seductress, carrying on an illicit affair with Acharya, who slowly shifts back into his life as a married man. What follows next is a series of engrossing events that eventually bring about a positive change in the relationships between the characters in the book.

There are many Indian Fiction novels and Indian Fiction authors, who have proved themselves internationally and have been appreciated globally. The Ultimate secret, by Ashwin Ramanujam Ashwin Ramanujam’s debut book “The Ultimate Secret” has made its mark on a fast pace, though it has been published in June, 2017, AR has already received accolades from all over the world. The story is based on protagonist Krishna, who leaves for the USA, to pursue Master’s Degree against his father’s wish. He remembers his father’s words “Remember you are the key”. Krishna’s knowledge about Indian history changes forever as he discovers that he is the key to the ultimate secret.  2. The Krishna Key, by Ashwin Sanghi The Krishna Key is based on protagonist, a historian by profession Ravi Mohan Saini, who is been blamed for the murder of his youthful best friend Anil Varshney. While trying to prove his innocence, Ravi investigates the past of Indian Mythology’s hazy areas and reveals reality about a serial executioner who believes himself to be Kalki, the last avatar of Lord Vishnu. Ravi goes from the old remains of the Lost City of Dwārakā to Vrindavan sanctuaries trying to find one of Krishna’s fortunes and prevent the executioner from killing his companions who are under the risk.  3. In The Name Of God, by Ravi Subramanian Irrespective of the plotline, Ravi sir's thrillers always come up with a fast-paced read, loads of unexpected twists and turns, powerful characterization and highly visualistic narrative. In The Name of God, the latest offering by the author recounts the multiple murders in and around the precincts of the famous Anantha Padmanabha Swami temple, known across the globe for its immense fortune and the adventurous journey of the investigators as they begin to unravel the biggest mystery.

Although technically it's a collection of 20 short stories, still its a compelling read. The book follows the migration of Aryans, over the course of time, from the bank of Volga river to the bank of Ganga. The 20 stories, though unrelated to each other, are arranged in accordance with movement of Aryans.  Written by the original Vagabond of Hindi Literature, MahaPandit Rahul Sankrityayan, Volga se Ganga is now considered a classic in history of Indian LiteratureFrom Wikipedia:"Volga Se Ganga is about the history of Indo–European people who were later known as the Aryans. The 20 stories are woven over a time span of 8000 years and a distance of about 10,000 km. This is a very good attempt at freeing our brains of the clutches of space and time. The first story Nisha is about cavemen living in Siberia about 6000 BC. The society or its precursor at that time was matriarchal and so the story is named after the leader of the family 'Nisha'. Although all the 20 stories are independent and equally enjoyable in their own right, the sequence in which they are arranged nevertheless serves a very important purpose. It is an indispensable aid to anyone who has been baffled by discontinuities in the evolution of societies and their cultures. Here one can find a gradual transformation from a matriarchal society (the first two stories) to a patriarchal one (the rest), a gradual change from freedom to slavery, from acceptance of slavery to its loathing and the likes. If we are to believe Sankrityayan then an apprehension for technological advancement is nothing new. People were wary of the newly better armament which was fast replacing the older stone equipment (Fourth story – Puruhoot (Tajikistan 2500BC.)). The same story tells us how an arms race was started during that period and how southerners amassed great wealth at the expense of the northerners. The sixth story Angira (Taxila 1800 BC) is about a man who wants to save the Aryan race from losing itself to other races by teaching about their culture (precursor toVedic Rishis). The eighth story (Pravahan (700 BC. Panchal, U.P.). is about the upper class manipulating religion for their own vested interests and conspiring to keep people in dark for at least 2000 years). One can see how easily and frequently the Indians, the mid easterners and the Greeks mingled with each other in the times of Chanakya and Alexander by reading the tenth storyNagdatt about a philosopher classmate of Chanakya who travels to Greece and learns how Athens fell to Macedonia. The eleventh story (Prabha, 50 AD) is about the famous (also the first Indian) dramatist Ashwaghosh, who adopted the Greek art of drama into Indian culture in a very beautiful and authentic way, and his inspiration. Baba Noordeen (1300), the 15th story is about the rise of Sufism. The seventeenth story Rekha Bhagat (1800 is about the barbarous rule of the East India company and the anarchy it brought to India. The last story (Sumer, 1942) is about a man who goes on to fight the Japanese because he wants Soviet Russia to triumph, for this nation (i.e., the Communist Party) is the only hope left for humanity."

Reckon, I best begin with a disclaimer, that I haven't read as many Indian authors as I wish I had. Having said that I have read enough to make my top ten list of them in no particular order.  The Terrorist - Juggi Bhasin: Edge of the seats, pant wetting thrills and the definition of a page turner. Bunker 13 - Anirudha Bahl: Published in early 2000 if I recall correctly and a proper good read. I read the case of exploding mangoes much, much later but I was reminded of Bunker 13 when I read it. Not sure who wrote what first but certainly a good read. Serious Men - Manu Joseph: It was funny and had those deep insights on the human psyche which lets you ruminate while you pursue the story. The Great Indian Novel - Shashi Tharoor: Masterclass in writing and appreciating satire, history and mythology. We are like that only - Rama Bijapurkar: Gives an understanding of how the emancipated Indian consumer thinks and behaves. Also gives you a lens to introspect your own buying/purchase behavior. Dongri to Dubai - Hussain Zaidi: Who doesn't love mafia stories? Especially when they are based on true living, breathing characters. Six Suspects - Vikas Swarup: The structure and formulation of the plot alone is worthy of a separate book. Swami and Friends - RK Narayan: Nostalgia galore!The Whole Byomkesh Series: Sherlock can suck it! Byomkesh and Ajit were the original intellectual sex symbols.  Sacred Games - Vikram Chandra: A lot of people take to this book like a regular whodunit. But it is to be consumed like a boat ride along a frustratingly long meandering river.I find that a lot of the regulars like English August, Namesake, Sea of Poppies to be highly over-rated to my bollywoodized sense and sensibilities.

Here are a few of my favourites, in no particular order -  1. The God of Small Things - Arundhati Roy  "They all crossed into forbidden territory. They all tampered with the laws that lay down who should be loved and how. And how much." Goodreads: The God of Small Things 2. The Great Indian Novel by Shashi Tharoor  In this award-winning, internationally acclaimed novel, Tharoor has masterfully recast the 2,000 year-old epic, The Mahabharata, with fictional but highly recognizable events and characters from twentieth-century Indian politics. Chronicling the Indian struggle for freedom and independence from Great Britain, Tharoor directs his hilarious satire as much against Indian foibles as the bumbling of the British rulers Goodreads : The Great Indian Novel 3. The Hungry Tide by Amitav Ghosh  Off the easternmost corner of India, in the Bay of Bengal, lies the immense labyrinth of tiny islands known as the Sundarbans, where settlers live in fear of drowning tides and man-eating tigers. Piya Roy, a young American marine biologist of Indian descent, arrives in this lush, treacherous landscape in search of a rare species of river dolphin and enlists the aid of a local fisherman and a translator. Together the three of them launch into the elaborate backwaters, drawn unawares into the powerful political undercurrents of this isolated corner of the world that exact a personal toll as fierce as the tides. Goodreads : The Hungry Tide 4. Malgudi Days by RK Narayan  Introducing this collection of stories, R. K. Narayan describes how in India 'the writer has only to look out of the window to pick up a character and thereby a story'. Malgudi Days is the marvellous result. Here Narayan portrays an astrologer, a snake-charmer, a postman, a vendor of pies and chappatis -- all kinds of people, drawn in full colour and endearing domestic detail. And under his magician's touch the whole imaginary city of Malgudi springs to life, revealing the essence of India and of human experience. GoodReads: Malgudi Days 5. The White Tiger by Aravind Adiga  The white tiger of this novel is Balram Halwai, a poor Indian villager whose great ambition leads him to the zenith of Indian business culture, the world of the Bangalore entrepreneur. On the occasion of the president of China’s impending trip to Bangalore, Balram writes a letter to him describing his transformation and his experience as driver and servant to a wealthy Indian family, which he thinks exemplifies the contradictions and complications of Indian society. Goodreads : The White Tiger

This man has to be one of the most influential Indian story tellers :  R.K. NarayanAn astute observer of human relations and a master story teller, he is definitely one of the leading figures of early Indian literature in English. He is famous for his lucid style and the idyllic settings of his novels. I present to you, two of his must read works :  The book deals with the naivete, wonder and mischief of ten year old Swaminathan. It is set in the idyllic fictional town of Malgudi and is quite nostalgic as it is reminiscent of the simple and carefree world, we all enjoyed as children and the one which the present day generation is devoid of. One can easily step into the boots of young Swami, as he and his friends, Rajam and Mani embark on several adventures.  (An image of Swami from the famous, Malgudi Days serial, directed by Shankar Nag.)Through his eyes, the reader gets to peek into the pre-independence days of South India. On the outset, this may seem like a simple story, but underneath, it is representative of a myriad of the feelings and emotions of Indians, born and brought up under the British Colonial Raj. To quote from a very good review by Harishankar : It is the story of a generation of Indians who are born and brought up  in the shadow of the British colonial Raj and who inherit the confusions  of the cultural and social conflict. This is best seen where Swami is seen alternatively admiring and envying Rajam: the rich boy who walks to  school dressed like a 'European'. Swami is caught between two worlds as  represented by Mani and Rajam. Rajam who stands for all that is posh  and urbane, smooth and unemotional, well educated yet hard and ruthless  in a way. The other end is Mani who is rough, untamed, naive, emotional  and yet loyal. The masterly irony is seen because these two characters  not only meet but (in Swami's eyes) they also apparently get along well. A highly readable novel that can be read on all levels. A must-read. Another of my favorite novels from the same author :   This book deals with transformation of an individual from a savage to a sage. R.K.Narayan masterfully carves out a beautiful sculpture out of the emotions and aspirations of a nondescript guide and dishes out a moving story marking his transformation from a caterpillar to a butterfly. Another must-read.

Amish Tripathi's "SHIVA TRILOGY".   It's very rare that we get a chance to read books that leave a humongous impact on us.I left Spell-Bounded , Wondered how deep he thought and paid attention to each and every detail  to create a novel like this.  ‘The IMMORTALS OF MELUHA’ , the first book of the Shiva trilogy is a No 1 National Bestseller, having sold over 100,000 copies since its launch in March, 2010. The story is narrated extremely well and way the characters are crafted is simply magical . One of the masterpiece of work by the author. He created a story around one of the most revered gods in Hindu mythology - Lord Shiva, who is portrayed as a simple human being.The mythological – historical – adventure – fiction series is all but immortalized as one of the trend changers amongst Indian books and Indian publishing as a whole. The series is creative, out-of-the-box and very much Indian. That exactly could be the reason why Amish is the latest Rockstar of Indian writing in English.  The book begins with introducing Shiva, who has been portrayed as a Tibetan Barbarian hailing from the warrior tribe (known in the book as the Gunas). He arrives in the fictional city of Meluha on the request of  King Daksha, whose land has been faced by terrorist attacks from the Chandravanshi tribe which he believes has allied with the Nagas – considered a lowly race - anyone from Meluha with a physical deformity is sent to be a Naga. While in Meluha, Shiva is recognized as the Neelkanth – an incarnation of the Mahadev, after he drinks the Somras – a healing potion, which makes his throat turns blue. Then follows the love story of Sati, daughter of King Daksha, and Shiva, which is undoubtedly one of my favorite parts in the entire series. Sati is a ‘Vikarma’ – an untouchable – and when she rejects Shiva’s advances, he challenges the law of Vikrama. In the book the word denotes an ‘untouchable’ who has to suffer in the present life due to the actions performed in the previous life. Amish Tripathi’s trilogy on Lord Shiva consists of three books, which have been released gradually over the past three years: ‘The Immortals of Meluha’, ‘The Secret of the Nagas’, and the much anticipated March-released finale, ‘The Oath of the Vayuputras’. In the second book the ‘Secret of the Nagas’, Shiva plays the role of being the savior who has left his homeland to fight evil. He and Sati are happily married. Along this path, Shiva learns that the Nagas are not evil, and that he had misjudged. The story explains how he realizes that metaphorically, a book cannot be judged by its cover. The cover of the book shows Shiva holding a snake which symbolizes evil, which he thought the Nagas represented.    Evil is finally revealed in the third book, ‘The Oath of the Vayuputras’.   Shiva takes it upon himself to fight against the fiercest of warriors, thereby leading the people away from what they believed to be good. And then, well, you can guess how it all ends!!

A more contemporary answer, both books by Karan Bajaj. Keep off the Grass: This book has been on bestseller lists in India since its release in 2008. The book was a semi-finalist for the Amazon Breakthrough Novel Award and shortlisted for the Indiaplaza Golden Quill Award, among other honors.     The story is about a psychedelic road trip of a 25-year-old Yale graduate through the length and breadth of India. The journey is made by a brilliant youngster named Samrat, born to immigrant parents in the U.S. who decides to go out in search of his roots. Along the way Samrat, the protagonist, ends up in prison for possession of marijuana, develops a drug addiction, meditates in the foothills of the Himalayas, has a one-night stand with a hippie in Dharamsala and meets flesh-eating Aghoree saints on the banks of Varanasi. I loved his second book too, Johnny Gone Down : This book has more action packed into it than a Die Hard film on steroids!   The novel is about the bizarre, almost surreal series of events that transform an Ivy League MIT graduate into first a genocide survivor, then a Buddhist monk, a drug lord, a homeless accountant, a software mogul, and a deadly game fighter over a period of twenty years.

I can not read Hindi very well, and I have not read too many English novels written by Indian authors, but here is my list from the books that I read - in no particular order Malgudi Days - RK Narayan It is a collection of short stories - each of which deftly describes an aspect of life in a small Indian town of 1940s ... One of the Indian classics, I think this book is extremely entertaining, and is an all time favourtie of mine.    Volga se Ganga - Rahul Sankrityayan Theists may well be offended by this novel, but I believe people should read this. (After all, respecting others opinion is an important part of growing up) It is a narration of the 'pre-history' of the Aryan race. Through the story of individuals Rahul Sankrityayan has wonderfully illustrated the soceital conditions and power equations of different periods in history upto the time the Aryan race settled in the Sindhu region and starting ruling over most of North India.   5.Someone - Chetan Bhagat or Immortals of Meluha - Amish Tripathi Disclaimer - This entire suggestion is biased by my personal dislike of a lot of books. That makes me club actually a very wide range of books under a single 'genre'. But you asked for an opinion, and am providing one. So try not being biased by my bias :-P I quite liked the first book of the Shiva Triology (The Immortals of Meluha by Amish Tripathi). So if you like my other suggestions, you should probably read that. But that is one of the very few 'modern Indian English novels' I liked. I really dislike Chetain Bhagat (and almost all 'modern' Indian authors writing in English for that matter). But many people really enjoy the genre, and it is stupidity to not try a genre. This is one of my least-disliked books from the genre and much more representative of the genre than The Immortals of Meluha. If you like any of these books, you should probably choose 5 (or at least 2) from Top 50 Indian English Novels(09-12)- TM List. If you like them, go on and read more :-)       The Namesake - Jhumpa Lahiri This novel captures the conflict of cultures many second generation immigrants face - on one side their parents expect them to hold on to their Indian root, on the other hand, their social and cultural environment is very disctinct from what their parents grew up in. Am not making a very good job to describing this book, so am copying from Wikipedia - Moving between events in Calcutta, Boston, and New York City, the novel examines the nuances involved with being caught between two conflicting cultures with highly distinct religious, social, and ideological differences.   If you like this novel, I think you should read the list here ::  Top 5 books by Indian writers in English you must read  Room on the Roof - Ruskin Bond Well I atleast consider Ruskin Bond an Indian - after all he spent his entire life here. If you do not, well read this all the same :-)  This is the story of an orphaned British boy - Rusty, with an Indian heart and strict British foster parents. It is one of the best Ruskin Bond I have ever read.

Nice question. I love reading Indian fiction, and there are quite a few authors who are my favorites: Rohinton Mistry, Salman Rushdie, Timeri Murari, David Davidar to name some. But there's one book that just takes the cake: It just has to be ‘The Illicit Happiness of Other People’ by Manu Joseph.  The story revolves around the happenings in a Malayali Catholic household in Madras of the ‘90s, soon after the eldest son inexplicably commits suicide. The tale then records the journey of the father (a once famous writer, who has now succumbed to the pull of the liquor bottle, transforming into a social outcast), who wishes to find out why exactly his son did what he did. The book is full of delectable quirky anecdotes that lay in plain sight the many hypocrisies of a middle-class community. Sample some of these lines: “The Boy will not be a failure. Mythili knows.She has seen the generations before.The boy will make it. As his father has said,he does not have the option of failure.He will crack atleast one entrance exam,and he will one day have a nice house in a suburb of San Francisco,or in a suburb of a suburb of San Francisco.He will find a cute Tamil Brahmin wife and make her produce two sweet children.He will drive a Toyota Corolla to work.And there,in the conference room of his office,he will tell his small team,with his hands stretched wide in a managerial way,'We must think out of the box”. What a brazen mocking of something we consider the norm! And more: “That breaks Ousep’s heart. To imagine the eternal boredom of his child. He wishes here to be no eternity, he wishes that even for his foes.” There is a whole slew of one-of-a-kind incidents, that one might find weird, astonishing even. But it’s this tone that makes the book a huge success. In the end, the reader learns that the story has little to do about the death as such, but endeavors to unravel a while lot more. Read the book for more. “In this world, it is very hard to escape happiness.” – Unni Chacko” . Cheers!

The Kama Sutra by Vatsayana   Contrary to popular perception, this ancient text is not just a manual of sexual positions. It is, in fact, the most comprehensive didactic discourse on the third Puruṣārtha [Ultimate Goal of Life], namely Kama [Aesthetic and Erotic Pleasure]. The reason I adjudge this text as "the best novels/books of all time by an Indian author" is not rooted in its innate popularity around the globe, nor do I claim that this book has the highest literary quality or is the most exulted form of art. But I do believe that this book has salvaged the concept of sexual congress from the perceived quagmires of sin and exulted it to the pedestal of art, exposing the literary quality of the act itself and thus making it one of the most popular routes of attaining a virtuous life as dictated by Hindu Philosophy.  Of course, Dharma (Virtue as Duty) and Artha (Monetary Prosperity) usually take precedence over Kama as Purusarthas. Therefore they have been treated more reverently and most texts from the ancient Hindu world deal with them. However, there is a sense of "duty" attached with both of these goals and "duty" has never been intrinsically welcome to the common man. Kama is, therefore, more appealing. It resonates with man's desire for Desire, it brings the pleasure of Pleasure and leads to the bliss of Bliss. And so, it is the common man's champion virtue. If anything, India is entirely composed of common folk and any treatise that assists the Indian common folk in the pursuit of their champion virtue is quite simply the best book that I would vote for.

1. Inheritance of Loss By Kiran Desai – The book is a fictional story of the retired Judge who is living alone in North East close to the Nepal border. The story progresses when his grand-daughter comes to live with him. The story covers how their life is intertwined between insurgencies, immigration and a lot more. 2. Interpreter of Maladies By Jhumpa Lahiri – A collection of nine short stories by the Indian American author. The stories are linked through a common thread of the immigration and tryst to protect the culture, religion and the identity. 3. Malgudi Days By R K Narayan – The book of tales from the fictional town of Malgudi, beautifully created and crafted by the author. Every story and character reflects a tale which would keep Malgudi in reader’s heart forever. 4. My Experiments with Truth By Mahatma Gandhi – The autobiography of the father of the Nation. 5. Midnight’s Children By Salman Rushdie – A brilliant tale set up in India around the time of independence and partition. The story is about the protagonist who has special powers because he was born right at the midnight hour and unites all other children born at midnight who are blessed with special power too. 6. Q & A By Vikas Swarup – A brilliant tale of a waiter winning the top prize in the general knowledge quiz show, the story of how he wins the show and finds love in his life.

Recently I have finsihed reading 'The Shiva Trilogy' by Amish Tripathi. One of my friends suggested me this and the time I started reading, there was no stopping. So what's so special about it, let's have a look: The way every scene is described whether it be love scene, war scene and introductory scene of a person(especially Sati), it appears to be realistic. You automatically start depicting that and the picture for that starts building in your mind.Most importantly the language is not that much difficult to understand, so don't worry about that.There is hell a lot of characters, but no need to worry again. The description of each character is provided initially in the book, so whenever you seem to be lost have a look and conitnue reading this brilliant piece of work.If you are a type of suspense lover guy, then these books are filled with it. You are also gonna love the style of unfolding the suspenses.The core message delivered by these books: What we think is our greatest good will eventually become our greatest bad, and vice versa is again another reason.Even Shashi Tharoor can't stop praising the work of Amish. OM NAMA SHIVAY THE UNIVERSE BOWS TO LORD SHIVA I BOW TO LORD SHIVA

The first book which I ever read and made a significant, everlasting impact on me was “THE GUIDE” by RK NARAYAN. PLOT: The story revolves around a lonely, dejected wife,ROSIE who has a passion for dance ,of a Workaholic archaeologist husband,MARCO and a happy guide RAJU. Neglected by her husband, Rosie finds comfort in arms of Raju who in turn motivates her to pursue her passion. Over a period of time when Rosie becomes successful, Raju begins to manage her performances but becomes greedy and and tries to accumulate more wealth for himself through her. However, he gets arrested for the forgery case and gets two years sentence. After completing the sentence, He is mistaken to be a SADHU, who would solve the famine problems of the village, and starts to enjoy luxuries provided to him by innocent and naive villagers. However, when the famine doesn’t end, he is asked to keep fast in order to make it rain. Ultimately, whether he dies or not, whether it rains or not, has not been answered in the novel. But the circle of life and changes in human nature, over a period of time (i.e. from simplicity to greed to generosity and again back to simplicity ), has been beautifully explained. It’s about a woman( reflecting a typical Indian woman) who wants to create her own identity but unable to do so because of the modern hypocritical society and as soon as she gets the necessary support, achieves the pinnacles of success. It’s about a passionate lover, who lets his greed and insecurities to come in middle his love and ultimately ends up destroying himself. It’s about an apathetic, cold husband who neglects his wife and considers her like a piece of furniture. In short, It’s about complexities of human-life, behavior and circle of life. How a person gets back to same place from where he once started? How a person in-spite of owning everything, ends up with nothing?

I hail from a land down in the South which goes by the name of Karnataka , the State which happens to have won the highest number of Jnanpith Awards .  Even with my limited acquaintance with Kannada literature , I could safely say that each one of the following books have been one-of-its kind and stands majestically amidst other excellent works that have been produced in Kannada .  Mr. D. V. G's Mankuthimmana Kagga - A major literary achievement , which is widely regarded as "Bhagavad Gita in Kannada"  for its philosophical overtone , yet noted for its simple way of narration with vivid illustrations , that could be even well understood by common people . More importantly, just like this fantastic work, the author's was also a life worth emulating .  Dr. Kuvempu's Sri Ramayana Darshanam - Through "Sri Ramayana Darshanam" , Mr. Kuvempu gave an altogether new dimension to the "epic" genre of literature . This magnum-opus based on the Hindu epic "Ramayana" is not just another version of Valmiki's story . Instead , Kuvempu's work amounts to an interpretative re-creation of the incidents, the characters and the philosophical, moral and spiritual ideas enshrined in Ramayana . Here , "Darshanam" in the title refers to the writer's "Vision" or his " Realization" .    Dr. K. Shivaram Karanth's "Mookajjiya KanasugaLu" ( The title literally translates to "Dreams of the silent granny" ) . This Avant-garde literary work with an abstract-philosophical theme is quite noted for Mr. Karanth's innovativeness and maturity in penning the character of mystified granny, the main female protagonist, who is quite contrary to the "stereotypical grandma". In the novel, through this astonishing granny, Mr. Karanth makes a bold attempt in unravelling the truth, criticizing the widely-accepted notions pertaining to many issues that are as subtle as - origin of the universe , the existence of some mysterious force, tragedies of human civilization, the adversities of casteism et cetera. It would be ungrateful of me , if I don't recollect the positive impacts which the novel had on me when I finished reading it .      Dr. Masti's historic novels - Chikka Virarajendra and Chennabasava Nayaka . If the former is based on the last ruler of Kodagu district,  the latter is about the last king among Nayakas of Shimoga. Both of these novels are quite remembered for the author's literary prowess. The prolific author was popularly referred to as "Maasti Kannadada Aasti" which means "Maasti is indeed Kannada's Treasure" .  Also, many other works of Dr. A. N. Krishna Rao (ANaKru),  Mr. T. R. Subba Rao ( TaRaSu) , Dr. S. L. Bhyrappa are also immensely popular .

The following books are a must read- A Fine Balance by Rohinton Mistry- This book is set during the emergency that was declared in India during the late 1900s. It traces the story of two poor tailors who come into the city to try their luck in earning money. They stay with a parsi widow who has recently lost her husband. She also boards her friend’s son who has come to the city for college. The story revolves around these four characters and their lives and how slowly they become more of a family than blood could ever make them. The story also subtly shows how most government policies are made without taking into consideration the common man’s plight. This book teaches many things and is sure to move your heart;even make you cry.The Namesake by Jhumpa Lahiri— This story is about an Indian family who migrates to the USA. It is about their life there and about the changes that they have to face. It also shows the differences in teenage lives and the loneliness that does come from having no relatives there. It shows that the grass may not always be greener on the other side and that happiness and satisfaction are subjective.Pather Panchali (Song of the road) by Bhibhutibhushan Bandhophadhyay— This book has been immortalised forever by Satyajit Ray in his Apu Trilogy. It is a story about a a poor family who live in the quiet village of Nishchindipur. It is a moving take about poverty and it's hardships. It beautifully portrays human nature and the simple innocence of children. It is a masterpiece.Do and Die by Mannini Chatterjee- This is a nonfictional account of the less known Chittagong uprising that took place in 1930-1934. It captures the essence of the Indian freedom movement and the contributions of many unsung heroes who are not named in our history books.The village by the sea by Anita Deasai- A heart rendering tale about a fisherman and his family that again traces human lives and hardships faced in poverty.Malgudi Days by RK Narayanan— A series of tales that will capture the hearts of any age group and can be read any number of times!The Adventures of Feluda by Satyajit Ray — A series of gripping mysteries that echo Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes. These mysteries are sure to keep you on the edge of your seat and heart racing!Wise and Otherwise by Sudha Murthy- A series of short inspiring tales that can be read anytime and in any order. They carry wisdom and guidance when you need it.All these books are in English or have English translations. These books show the talent that Indian authors really possess- bringing out human nature at its best and worst. I owe these books much of the wisdom I have gained and for getting to know my country for what it really is and appreciating it.

It seems that no one has mentioned any Bengali novels so far although Bengali literature is among the most prolific in India if not in the world in producing novels. They are widely read, extremely popular, have been translated into many languages and inspired scores of Indian movies. I will mention a few of them.  1. Anandamathh- Bankim Chandra     One of the most controversial and influential novels in not only Bengal but the entire country. It is a novel about the Sanyasi rebellion against the British written in the 19th century. It provided the first intellectual background to fuse Hindu religious imagery into the political movement for freedom. The concept of Bharatmata was first envisaged in this book. The slogan Vande Mataram also comes from this book. It inspired the Swadeshi movement, it is even fair to say that it gave birth to it. 2. Srikanto- Sarat Chandra Chattopadhyay Srikanto is a massive novel about the life of a middle class Bengali boy born in rural Bengal from his childhood to his adult life. Perhaps no other novel depicts the rural life of Bengal as completely as this.    It has inspired many Bengali movies and stories for countless movies in other languages. 3. Pather Panchali and Aparajito- Bibhutibhushan Bandopadhyay The movie trilogy which has immortalized Stayajit Ray and is widely considered as one of the most important work in world cinema ever is inspired from these two novels which were sequels and guess what? Satyajit Ray can only claim to have done justice to it. Yes the novel is so good.      The story depicts the life of Apu who is a boy born to a poor Brahmin family in rural Bengal and his epic struggle throughout his life amid monumental tragedies as he grows up. It is a story of the triumph of life over death. Here is the last scene from the Apu Trilogy of Satyajit Ray. Apu is visiting his orphaned son with whom he had no contacts after his birth as the boy's mother (Apu's wife) died during childbirth and Apu has had grudged the boy since then. The boy does not know that Apu is his father.    4. Putulnacher Itikothha- Manik Bandopadhyay. Manik is widely considered one of the 6 literary greats of Bengal. The others being Bankimchandra, Sarat Chandra, Rabindranath Tagore, Tarashankar and Bibhutibhushon Bandyopadhyay.    It is a magnum opus depicting the lives of peasants in rural Bengal amid the Tebhaga movement of 1930's. It played a great role in politicizing the middle class of Calcutta. It is a historical account of life of rural Bengal during the first half of 20th century. 5. Ganadevata-Tarashankar Another great novel on rural Bengal and how the landed class exploited the poor in Bengal. This is set in post independence period and therefore shows how the landed class enjoyed political patronage and covered their dirty business using political might. 6. Hatey Bajare- Banaful Another wonderful novel on the struggle of an educated middle class Bengali trying to fight against religious malpractices and various social stigma in rural Bengal. It has been adopted into an award winning Bengali film. Banaful has many other stories which have been adopted in to national award winning Hindi movies like Bhuvan Shome and Vikram Pandit.

1. A Suitable Boy by Vikram Seth  ​Image SourceWhy read it? This is a story of ordinary people set in post- independence Indian background, who are looking for a suitable boy for Lata’s marriage. Lata is 19 and she believes in falling in love first. There’s not only the pursuit of marriage and happiness but heartache and disappointment, which is universal. Throughout its sprawling 1474 pages, there was no emotion left unexplored and no character left misunderstood. 2￼. English, August: An Indian Story by Upamanyu Chatterjee  ​Image SourceWhy read it? If you have been to any government office or if you’re working there, then this book is a must read. Upamanyu Chatterjee has presented how things work in an Indian office and it’s refreshingly funny. The story revolves around Agastya Sen and how his life changes when he goes to Madna, a small town. The author has also drawn heavily from his own experience in the Indian administrative service to paint a picture of rural India.3. The God of Small Things by Arundhati Roy  ​Image SourceWhy read it? Roy’s debut novel is a masterpiece. The book pivots around tragedy and hope. The book also explores the full range of human emotion.4. The Inheritance of Loss by Kiran Desai  ​Image SourceWhy read it? Despite the humor and wittiness encompassing it, The Inheritance of Loss remains a powerful book written with sheer honesty. Theinner struggles of the characters could not be conveyed any better. Desai has the capacity to place the exact words on the most abstract feelings! The book is unflinchingly honest. My favorite quote from this book is: ”Sadness was so claustrophobic’.”5. Interpreter of Maladies by Jhumpa Lahiri  ​Image SourceWhy read it? The 9 stories present are a smashing success. Lahiri paints the character’s picture so well that you can relate to an old gatekeeper or a wife feeling lonely and disoriented in a new and unfamiliar home and culture or the young college grad who gets into an affair with a married man. Lahiri’s main characters are all always flawed, but what makes them stand out is how familiarly human they are.6. The White tiger by Aravind Adiga  ​Image SourceWhy read it? The novel examines issues of religion, caste, loyalty, corruption and poverty in India. The story revolves around Balram, who worked his way out from his low social caste and how he became successful and how he overcame all the social obstacles.7. The Blue Umbrella by Ruskin Bond  ​Image SourceWhy read it? It is set in the hills of Garhwal and captures the life of villagers who portray heroic characters. Basically, it captures the life in a village.8. The Palace Of Illusions by Chitra Banerjee Divakaruni  ​Image SourceWhy read it? Banerjee has written the whole story by stepping into Draupadi’s shoes and writing a completely male dominant epic from a female’s point of view. Her description of emotions like insecurity, jealousy, and love are amazing. No doubt this is the best fictional account of the Mahabharat.9. The Great Indian Novel, Shashi Tharoor  ​Image SourceWhy read it? In this novel, Tharoor has masterfully recast the Mahabharata. He has compared the political figures of India with the characters of the Mahabharat. It’s basically a retelling of the Indian epic, but it falls in the realm of political satire by drawing parallels with major events in India’s political history during the freedom movement and the post-independence era.

PONNIYIN SELVAN BY KALKI KRISHNAMOORTY.  Ponniyin Selvan is a historical novel that centers on a number of real historical characters and incidents. The oldest evidence available about the Chola dynasty is about the Chola kings Karikal Peruvalathan, Killivalavan, Nedunkilli, and Perunkilli, among others. After this, the trail runs cold and resurfaces as Vijayalaya Chola once again established the Chola dynasty after defeating the Pandiyas and the Pallavas. The story about rajaraja chola,rival between pandyas and cholas,spying techniques ,betrayal ,romance ,revenge ,shocking twist and turns,politics.This story almost covered all the topics. This book is the best seller book in tamilnadu book fair every year. It is also available in english too.  There is also a play about ponniyin selven held in tanjore every year. Why it is so intresting? Because the places refered in the books are still there. TANJORE  PAZAYARAI  KUMBAKONAM AIRAVATHESWARER TEMPLE BUILT BY THE SON OF KUNTHAVAI AND VANTHIYADEVAN LEAD CHARACTER IN THE STORY.

I would just mention the names  of some of the most amazing novels by Indian, I have read till now - 1)Premchand -Nirmala and Rang Bhoomi We all have read about Premchand in our school days, but whatever you have imagined is far lesser than the beauty and essence of his writings. Sadly I have read only these two novels till now. He has many more which are much more famous and world known. His novels are based on real life characters, real life settings, same person becomes an evil and a messenger of god at different points of time. He weaves the complexity of our existence, actions and decisions in such a beautiful manner that you will be surprised on the perception and portrayal of the writer. He is the best novelist I have ever read, who could write stories on day to day life yet make it the best you will ever read.  2) Rashmi Bansal - Connect the Dots, Stay Hungry Stay Foolish and I have a dream. These books are based on real life difference makers, presented in a manner that you feel connected to it and imagine yourself to be in her place, interviewing these people, mesmerized by the words of these men/women who have lived life of meaning  and made so many life's better because of them. Awesome books and must read. 3) Amitav Ghosh - The Hungry Tide, The Glass PalaceThe Stories of Amitav Ghosh are not some far fetched reality, they are our very own day to day people, whose life is woven beautifully almost magically to take you to all together different level of understanding. Facets of human nature are depicted in most subtle manner and the setting of novel is almost sure to make you mesmerized and read the book till it ends. Even then you will keep thinking about the characters, the landscape, the story and the end. One awesome writer of today. 4)  Amish Tripathi - Shiva Triology No need to say how beautifully written it is. Again the story is just amazing, and all your thoughts till now and religious stories you have heard till now, take a new face and all together new existence. Amazing and definitely a must read. 5)  Manoj Das-Tiger at TwilightThe way he writes is superb. I read this novel focusing more on the writing than story as it is so very amazing. A very nice novel.   6) Jaya, illustrated retelling of Mahabharata - Devdutt PattanaikHe shows Mahabharata stories with all its forms and interpretations. Nicely written and entertaining read. 7) Swami and Friends - R.K. NarayanWho can forget the beautiful world of Malgudi, it is a treasure of our childhood days as well. Most amazing, innocent and heart-touching stories you can read. 8) Idli, Orchid and Will Power - Vikram KamatA very inspiring book written in a very engaging manner.

Let's start with authors that you shouldn't bother about though they are very popular - books by Amish and Chetan Bhagat. They will only entertain you but will not enrich you. I believe that books should startle you with language or give you a new perspective on life or make you think. Along with this, they should entertain you. Chetan Bhagat and Amish only do the latter. They are written for young guys who want easy language and spicy stories. Based on the above criteria, here are the ones I would recommend: The Shadow Lines, The Glass Palace, The Hungry Tide, and Dancing in Cambodia by Amitav Ghosh English August by Upamanyu Chatterjee God of small things by Arundhati Roy A Fine Balance and Such a Long Journey by Rohinton Mistry Midnight's Children and The Satanic Verses by Salman Rushdie A New World by Amit Chaudhuri Anything by Ruskin Bond Do read translated small stories by Rabindranath Tagore There are Indian origin writers such as Pico Iyer and VS Naipaul that are masters of the craft. You can also read Ramchandra Guha and Ashis Nandy for non-fiction on Indian society. Haven't read Shashi Deshpande and Romila Thapar. But Gita Mehta's Karma Cola and A River Sutra are nice. Will add more as I remember

I would recommend ‘The god of small things' by Arundhati Roy and R.K Narayanan’s works. Former is a story of two siblings who got separated at an early age and the consequences. R K Narayan's books are one of the finest narratives of the tales of the late sixties of India. But, I will recommend you to read books of Indian languages. India has rich literature - Bengal and Tamil known for its good novellas. Urdu famous for its shayarees. In Kannada, you'll get a bunch of good authors who made Kannada literature as a profound one. Kuvempu, Karantha, Tejaswi, Ananthamurty (list continuous) to list a few. Devanuru Mahadeva, Siddalingyyah have picturised how it feels to grow as an oppressed community. Yashwanth chittal narrated many stories in a manner which is similar to that of Kafka's style. U R Ananthmurty's debut novel Samskara was on the final list of Man Booker award in the year 2014. Vivek Shanubhag's Ghachar Ghochar received a positive review by NYT. I've heard quite about Malayalam literature. Khasakkinde ithihasam, aadu jeevitham etcetera. These books are in my bucket list.

#1 The Last Song Of Dusk by Siddharth Dhavant Shanghvi The Last Song of Dusk was Siddharth Shanghvi’s debut novel that went to win an International bestseller. The book won Betty Trask Award (one of UK’s most prestigious awards). Set in 1920s, the book follows the story of girl named Anuradha, who moves to Bombay, after getting married to Vardhmaan (a doctor by profession). The couple are soon blessed with a child but their happiness is short-lived. While mending their relationship, the couple learn the true-meaning of love.  #2 The God Of Small Things By Arundhati Roy One of the Best Indian novels to read, The God of Small Things won Booker Prize in 1997. It remained Arundhati Roy’s first and only book till 2017. The book explores different human emotions. The story revolves around Ipe family. Ammu Ipe escapes to Kolkata from Kerala and marries a man. They have fraternal twins, Rahel and Estha but the marriage is short-lived. Tired of her husband’s abuse, Ammu goes back to Kerala with her children. At the tender age of 7, children are separated and Ammu dies at the age of 31.  #3 The Immortals Of Meluha By Amish Tripathi The Immortals of Meluha is the first novel of Shiva Trilogy and also debut novel of author, Amish Tripathi. Considered to be one of the best mythology-fiction book, The Immortals of Meluha follows the journey of Shiva from an ordinary human being to a supreme god. The book was initially rejected by many publication houses, Tripathi’s agent decided to publish book by himself. The first chapter of the book was available to download for free. Also Read: Popular Indian Mythology Books by Indian Authors  #4 The Palace Of Illusions By Chitra Banerjee Divakaruni Chitra Banerjee Divakaruni’s first book, arranged marriage won American Book Award in 1995. Published in 2008, The Palace of Illusions is an interpretation of epic MAHABHARATA’ from Draupadi’s point of view, who sheds light on a woman living in a world of patriarchy. The book explores her relationship with pandavas, her mother-in-law Kunti and her best friend, Krishna.  #5 White Tiger By Aravind Adiga Aravind Adiga’s debut novel, White Tiger, won him Booker prize in 2008. The story is told from the viewpoint of Balram Halwai who moves from a small village to Gurgaon and then to Bangalore. Balram works as a servant at a teashop in Dhanbad. He considers himself a good listener and learns to drive a car. He soon becomes a chauffeur and drives car for Ashok and his wife, Pinky. The trio move to Gurgaon where Balram sees corruption at every level. The story takes a turn when Ashok’s wife, while drunk, hits something and runs away. Ashok begins to pressurize Balram to take the blame. What happens next is the crux of the book.

The Great Indian Novel by Shashi Tharoor    As the author himself claims at the beginning of the book, there is nothing he considers 'great' about the novel, neither is it a typical 'Indian' tale, nor does it follow a standard 'novel style. The title alludes to what the author considers THE Great Indian Novel - The Mahabharata.   The author successfully, and - more often than not - hilariously recasts the characters of the Mahabharata as the political honchos and the who's who of 20th century India.  The modern twist on the tale begins as the 80 year-old Ved Vyas (known as V. V. in his social circles! ), at the advice of his good friend, Brahm, hires as an amanuensis ,the diligent, South Indian, Ganapathi. V.V.'s musings give form the rest of the story - Gandhiji becomes Gangaji, Indira Priyadarshini becomes, Gandhari and Dhritasrashtra's daughter, Priya Duryodhani, as the author superposes mythical tales from the Mahabharatawith historical facts from pre-Independence to newly independent India. Packed full of references and nods to characters and events from the original epic, this is a generations-spanning story, incredibly well-researched by the former UN Under-Secretary General and award-winning author Shashi Tharoor.

Thanks for A2A. Curfewed Night by Basharat Peer,    Basharat Peer was a teenager when the separatist movement exploded in Kashmir in 1989. Over the following years countless young men, seduced by the romance of the militant, fuelled by feelings of injustice, crossed over the Line of Control to train in Pakistani army camps. Peer was sent off to boarding school in Aligarh to keep out of trouble. He finished college and became a journalist in Delhi. But Kashmir angrier,more violent, more hopeless was never far away. In 2003, the young journalist left his job and returned to his homeland to search out the stories and the people which had haunted him. In Curfewed Night he draws a harrowing portrait of Kashmir and its people. Here are stories of a young man's initiation into a Pakistani training camp; a mother who watches her son forced to hold an exploding bomb; a poet who finds religion when his entire family is killed. Of politicians living in refurbished torture chambers and former militants dreaming of discotheques; of idyllic villages rigged with landmines, temples which have become army bunkers, and ancient sufi shrines decapitated in bomb blasts. And here is finally the old story of the return home and the discovery that there may not be any redemption in it.

Madhushala, Harivansh Rai BacchanIt is a book of 135 "quatrains": verses of four lines (Ruba'i) by Hindipoet and writer Harivansh Rai Bachchan (1907–2003). The highly metaphorical works Shyam, Radha's husband, who can only watch helplessly as she embraces Chris with a passion that he has never been able to draw from her. Also playing the role of observer-participant is Koman; his life story, as it unfolds, captures all the nuances and contradictions of the relationships being made--and unmade--in front of his eyes.   Midnight's Children, Salman RushdieSaleem Sinai was born at midnight, the midnight of India's independence, and found himself handcuffed to history by the coincidence. He is one of 1,001 children born at the midnight hour, each of them endowed with an extraordinary talent. This is a family saga set against the background of the India of the 20th century.   Train to Pakistan, Khushwant Singh This is a story about the village of Mano Majra, it is a place, Khushwant Singh goes on to tell us at the beginning of this classic novel, where Sikhs and Muslims have lived together in peace for hundreds of years. Then one day, at the end of the summer, the “ghost train” arrives, a silent, incredible funeral train loaded with the bodies of thousands of refugees, bringing the village its first taste of the horrors of the civil war. Train to Pakistan is the story of this isolated village that is plunged into the abyss of religious hate. It is also the story of a Sikh boy and a Muslim girl whose love endured and transcends the ravages of war.

You can't find more epic book than this - महाभारतम्. The Mahabharata is roughly ten times the length of the Iliad and the Odyssey combined, and four times Ramayana. So you will understand why it is called EPIC. The oldest reference to them dated back to approx. 5th century BCE, but the actual writing is much older than that, dating back to almost 9th century BCE. Literature-wise, there is no match to the grandeur and complexity of Mahabharata. To compare it with Shakespeare would be shaming them (and that is no exaggeration). [Further read: What elements of “Mahabharata” make it timeless, and what are the basic lessons we can learn from it?] You can also give a read to Kālidāsa's work, especially मेघदूतम् which is considered to be one of the best works of literature. [Also see Gauri Noolkar's answer to In your culture, what are some literary classic books?]

The Shiva Trilogy by Amish. By far one of the best books I've ever read combining both foreigner and indian authors. This series tells us the story of a common, tribal man named Shiva who existed centuries ago, and goes on to become the Mahadev. He is recognized all over India as the destroyer of evil just because he has a blue throat. The book follows his journey as he goes on to find true evil and eventually destroying all of it. This book has been written in such a way that the youth of the country find parallel with it. It is nothing like those old mythological tales. Shiva here, goes on destroying all of those old-school ways of hindu living including The SATI practice and much more. The three books make Shiva the ideal man for the title of The god of gods, the Mahadev. The story in each step keeps unravelling secrets and keeps readers thrilled and ensures that they reach the end of the book quickly. The story has love, mystery, secrets, war, philosophy all rolled as one with the central character Shiva. Do read it.

I have a limited experience in reading works by Indian authors, but here is my two cents Any work by Ruskin Bond- all short stories and novels by Ruskin Bond- transport you into a type of India that is incredibly difficult to see now a days. The way the lush scenery and beauty of living in the mountains has been described, you might just feel like packing your bags and moving to a hill station! :-DAll works by R K Narayangan. Especially Malgudi daysRabindranath Tagore- all his short stories make you realise how different life was in rural Bengal. Plus you get to learn some Bengali too ;)The white tiger- by Arvind Adiga.There is no way to describe this book except that it is nothing like you have ever read before. The crass language used in some parts serves to make it even more Indian!

Shiva Trilogy By Amish Tripathi Because once you are hooked, it's impossible to leave the book(any of them). Facts and fiction merge seamlessly. Some really nice books listed here. Lately, my eyes caught this one, The Lost Temple. I finished it in a day. I thought it needs to be listed among best books by Indian authors.  It's a fast paced action thriller that combines mythology, archaeology, military technology and nuclear science. The story moves with number of different elements and groups that the author, Vishesh Sharma, has managed to bring together through the story. one can read sample chapter at Author Vishesh - The Lost Temple   The story moves on multiple dimensions and authors displays his command on subjects as diverse as military equipment and ancient Indian temple architecture. There is a high suspense thrill in the story and of course there is a romantic angle that develops as the story moves.  Not many contemporary authors can achieve the kind of flow author has managed to bring in coupled with his knowledge of different subjects. In the age of over analysis it is nice to see someone working on bringing synthesis amongst different subjects – linking the modern to the ancient. We need many more works that synthesize out thought process rather than break everything for microanalysis.

It is difficult to select one best book among the vastly spanned course of Indian literature; but down below I am listing few of them which I have liked the most and always use them as reference in my life. Shyam-chi aai in Marathi (Shyam's Mother in English) by - Sane Guruji  What the book is about? Set in the British Raj, this book is an autobiography of social activist Sane Guruji(fondly called Shyam during his childhood) who belonged to a Brahmin family living in Konkan region of Maharashtra.In the book he is narrating his memories to a group of children in an nightly sitting.The central character of this book is Shyam's mother and the kind of enormous influence she has on Shyam's life and upbringing. It involves sticking to one's ideals even though one is neck deep in abject poverty. Why one should read this book ?The narration is flamboyant and involves readers in the setting smoothly. As the story progresses, we come to know the deterioration of Shyam's debt-ridden family. The communication between father and son, mother and son, and siblings is exemplary. It shows if love is present a person's life can be content no matter how poor he is. Achievements:The book was adapted into a movie by none other than Acharya Atre, one of the finest talent in Maharashtra's film and theatre culture.The movie won President's medal as The Best Feature Film award at the first National Awards held in 1954.Over the years this book has made a special spot in Marashtrian households. PS: Munshi Premchand's Godaan is also another brilliantly written book worth mentioning

Across the Black Waters - by Mulk Raj Anand This is the story of Indian soldiers from the British Raj's army being sent to fight in the First World War for Britain. This is a terrific read and gives a glimpse into an unexplored portion of History. Godan (The Gift of a Cow) - by Premchand As language has not been mentioned in the question, I must include this epic book. Even if you are not great at reading Hindi, go read a translation. An absolutely fascinating book about the Indian people. A Flight of Pigeons - by Ruskin Bond This is a fictional account of a British mother daughter duo who are abducted by an Indian mutineer in 1857 because he is smitten by the daughter. Another excellent book which really brings the famous revolt of 1857 to life as seen by common people and civilian Britishers of the time. Bonus: Also made into an excellent film by Shyam Benegal, so you can go watch it after you have finished the book. (http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077783/)

The Mother I Never Knew: Two Novellas by Sudha Murty: Yet another book from the treasure trove of Sudha Murty, The Mother I Never Knew: Two Novellas is a poignant tale of two men, Venkatesh and Mukesh, as they set out on a journey to find out the mothers they never knew. Both men are happy and settled in their respective lives when they come across a shocking truth. When Venkatesh realises he has a half-brother from his father's extramarital liaison, his world changes. He finds his step-mother out and is pained to see the pitiful condition she is living in. He must make amends for what his father has done but the question that haunts him deep within is if it is really possible to undo everything. Mukesh is in a similar state of agony when he comes to know that he was adopted as a kid. Pushed by impulse, he decides to find his biological mother. But the farther he goes, the more unclear the picture becomes. He must decide towards whom his true love and loyalty lies: the woman whom he called his mother all his life and who raised him or the woman who has given him birth. The two men are bound by the same dilemma and the same complexity of emotions. and it is important for them to find their way back to bring stability in their lives. The core interest of the book is in exploring if it is really possible to come to terms with a reality as blaring and as deceiving as that of Venkatesh and Mukesh.

Yayati: A Classic Tale of Lust,  by V. S.Khandekar It is one of the most intriguing and fascinating story of Mahabharata.One of the most exciting reads. The story of  King Yayati and his passions, unending desires of lust.A simple story intertwined in the POV of different characters. Characters have to make choices all the time, between what they want and what duty calls, between good and bad, between bad and worse, between ego and devotion, between family and society, between themselves and their partners, between now or later, between ages and eras and everything that comes in between. The most awesome part of the book is the symbolism the author has used to compare this ancient story with the modern times. It opens your mind to a lot of new perspectives. This novel has won the highest literary awards in India - Jnanpith Award & Sahitya Academi Award.I would strongly recommend this book to anyone interested in reading quality Indian literature, and anyone interested in India’s historical literature.

I would like to suggest a Marathi book and I don't know if you will be able to find a translated version of it but it is indeed a great book.  Shyamchi Aai is an autobiography by Sane Guruji. It is hailed as one of the greatest if not the greatest tribute to mother's love in Marathi literature. This book is the story of Sane Guruji and his family. It shows how his family, coming from a wealthy background, became poor and struggled through that period. As the book's title suggests the main character is his mother. It is a story where a mother teaches her kid to stick to their ideals even if they are neck deep in abject poverty. This book is a great story of a mother's love for her child. It was indeed recommended to me by my mother.

Three books, hmmm… that’s too few! Mahabharata - by Vyasa - may sound a little too religious, believe me, I am not that into religion. I admire this book for the plot, for the variety of characters it show cases and mostly for the way you can correlate the story to today’s life. Not convinced… try this, take the organisation you work for, analyse and find the ‘real boss’, you will surely have a ‘Bheeshma - dedicated righteous person, ‘Shakuni’ - the cunning management interface etc.Malgudi Days (and many other books) - by R.K.Narayanan - it portrays the lifestyle in South India of those times. But there are a good number of elements that relate to our daily life and characters of today!Wings of Fire (& Ignited Minds) by A.P.J. Randamoozham by M.T.Vasudevan Nair. Title is in Malayalam and means 'Second Turn'. It is the Mahabharatha from the viewpoint of Bhimsena(n), the second of the Pandava brothers. What is so brilliant about this book is that it takes all the mythical and fantastic elements and reinterprets them based on reality. Over the course of the book, you realise that - Yudhisthira is a wimp.Dhritarashtra didn't have 100 kids because his wife gave birth to a mass of flesh which was cut into 100 pieces. He had 100 kids because he had sex with (a.k.a. fucked) multiple women in the palace, ranging from the serving maids to the cleaning ladies.Kunti didn't have children because she recited a mantra and invoked a god to give her a child. She had children because she had sex with people other than her husband.Pandu didnt father any children with his wives because he was cursed with death if he did so. He was impotent.Explanations that are much more simple and practical, methinks. Sad part is that this book is not available in English ('Second Turn' was published, but it is out of print now. I heard that the publishers are planning to release another run). If you can read Malayalam, please please read this. You will not regret it.

Chanakya neeti Author: Chanakya  world famous leader, economist and politician. Chanakya is known for his extraordinary skills in government, politics, life science and human psychology. He is remembered as the foundation pillar of starting Maurya Rule and the diminishment of Nanda Rule in India. His books including the Sampoorn Chanakya Neeti are still significant and effective to follow in our daily lives, business and in organisations. The principles in this book are written in a well formed Sanskrit Shloka where every single one is a source of immense intellectual treasure. I am reviewing and summarising the book and including some of the very popular quotes from the book. The book is over 2000 years old but the principles given in it are like, more significant in today’s world. The book is a source of domestic, social and intellectual wisdom which covers thoughts of Acharya Chanakya from a wide domain. Here are the topics you can expect to learn in the book Relationship wisdom between wife and husbandTeacher and student valuesFinancial wisdomFriendship wisdomHuman psychology of man and womanUnderstanding of Trust and loyaltyImportance of Education and knowledgeStudent goals and disciplineResponsibility of various people like teachers, businessman, students etcAnd finally The secrets of a happy life

Having read quite a few of them (I have read well over 5,000+ books and possess over 1,000+ in my home library); I would suggest perusal of these 6 mentioned below. I consider that each of these authors played a vital role in establishing Indian Contemporary English writing in the West and went a long way establishing the fact… that Asians have the intellectual capability and articulation and poise and maturity to excel as a major contributor to English World Literature. If we purely judge in terms of critical acclaim and recognition amongst pundits and critiques… here's my top 6:- A Suitable Boy by Vikram SethInterpreter of Maladies by Jhumpa LahiriThe Hungry Tide by Amitav GhoshThe Glass Palace by Amitav GhoshMidnight’s Children by Salman RushdieThe God of Small Things by Arundhati RoyThere's 2 more which are the greatest and probably 2 of the best written novels ever… but Sir V. S. Naipaul doesn't exactly qualify as an Indian writer since though Indian origin; he was born in Trinidad & Tobago. The Calcutta chromosome by Amitav Ghosh:   Yes, this is a great book. The recipient of the prestigious Arthur C Clarke award, this intriguing tale with a plot revolving around the research of Malaria, never lets go. The characters feel real and it is an engaging, not-over-the-top science fiction. Amitav Ghosh's prose is fresh and unpretentious.  A Fine Balance by Rohinton Mistry A brutal, realistic account of a group of people, how their lives intersect during the time of emergency. Rohinton Mistry deftly handles the change in narrative and shows us a picture of one of the most tumultous periods of India. This one was an out and out winner for me.

2 books written by Anand Neelkanthan- Ajaya and Asura- are definitely worth reading!Both the books are mythological fiction, but from the point of view of the underdogs. Ajaya is the tale of the kaurava brothers, mainly focusing on Duryodhan (as the good guy, of course). Asura, on the other hand, is Ramayna retold where Ravana, with all his arrogance and pride, was only a man who did what he felt was in the best interests of his kin. Anand Neelkanthan, exceeds all creativity and imagination! Both the books are full of twists and turns! It becomes difficult to keep the book down once you start! But then again, that's my opinion. Happy reading! :)

Indian literature cannot be discussed without mentioning the epics Ramayana and Mahabharata. Narayanan, Ruskin Bond, Sudha Moorthy. These authors cater to any bookworm, kids and adults alike      And if you think you are too old for short stories (which you can never be.... !!) then dive into the bookers club, to name a few Salman Rushdie, Arundhati Roy, Kiran Desai.....       and this is just the tip of iceberg, unravel more according to your taste and liking.
