1.Abdul Kalam Wings Of Fire  Wings of Fire: An Autobiography of A P J Abdul Kalam, former President of India. It was written by Dr. Kalam and Arun Tiwari. Kalam examines his early life, effort, hardship, fortitude, luck and chance that eventually led him to lead Indian space research, nuclear and missile programs. 2.Life is What you make it By Preeti Shenoy  Life Is What You Make It is a novel by Preeti Shenoy. The book was in “Top books of 2011” as per the Nielsen list which is published in Hindustan Times. It was also on Times of India all-time best sellers of 2011. This is an astonishing love story set in India in 1990s. 3.The Golden Stories of Dadagari Jeelan by Dadagari Jeelan  The Book Of Many Novels,Some best Novels Like “,The Poor Children’s Life” are explicitly encapsulated in a maxim.The Other Best Novels are design with magicals of God. “The Sensitive Plant”, “Mother’s Love”,and “Gamdhiji and Selfish Passeneger’s” are some Best Novels in the Book. 4.The Suitable Boy by Vikram Seth  A Suitable Boy is a novel by Vikram Seth, published in 1993. At 1,349 pages and 591,552 words, the book is one of the longest novels ever published in a single volume in the English language. A sequel, to be called A Suitable Girl, was due for publication in 2017. 5.The God of Small Things by Arundati Roy  The God of Small Things is the debut novel of Indian writer Arundhati Roy. It is a story about the childhood experiences of fraternal twins whose lives are destroyed by the "Love Laws" that lay down "who should be loved, and how. And how much. 6.Train to Pakistan by Khushwant Singh  Train to Pakistan is a historical novel by Khushwant Singh, published in 1956. It recounts the Partition of India in August 1947. 7.Mrs Funny Bones  Mrs Funnybones: She’s Just Like You and a Lot Like Me is a 2015 Indian non-fiction book written by former film actress Twinkle Khanna and published by Penguin India. Mrs Funnybones sold over one lakh copies making Twinkle Khanna India's highest-selling female writer of 2015. One Indian Girl By Chetan Bhagat  One Indian Girl is the seventh fictional novel and the ninth overall book written by the Indian author Chetan Bhagat.Moving to the book then, “One Indian Girl” is a story of a girl called Radhika Mehta who is a hot-shot banker working in the prestigious Investment Bank, Goldman Sachs. Radhika, who once was as nerdy as one can be, is now arranged to get married to Brijesh Gulati and has just arrived for her destination wedding in Goa. 8.The White Tiger by Arvind Adiga  The White Tiger is the debut novel by Indian author Aravind Adiga. It was first published in 2008 and won the 40th Man Booker Prize in the same year. 9.PASHMINA By Nidhi Chanani  Pashmina is a debut graphic novel written by Nidhi Chanani. The novel focuses on the relationship between an Indian-American mother and her teenage daughter. 10.THE GUEST By Mitali Meelan  Eighteen-year-old Neha Ranade is perfectly content with her life-a singer boyfriend, a group of loyal friends and with the college annual festival around the corner, her days are full and exciting. But when her father's Canadian colleague arrives home, Neha's grand plans are uprooted. What could be the intentions of this curious guest's sudden visit-for better or for worse?

The Strange Case of Billy Biswas by Arun Joshi'The Strange Case of Billy Biswas is a compellingly thought provoking novel. A novel in which the normal and the abnormal, the ordinary and the extraordinary, illusion and reality, resignation and desire to rub shoulders.The protagonist, Billy Biswas, is a man of extraordinary passions. He has everything going for him - education, wealth, status, travel and a loving wife. Yet his inner world is rocked by a groundswell of discontent. He is consumed by a restlessness which grows steadily...Characterised by great elan and sophistication, the narrative unfolds in quick succession, and would be hard to believe were it not related in such a matter of fact, down to earth manner.' -- Orient Paperbacks Beyond the Last Blue Mountain - A Life of JRD Tata by R.M. LalaA biography of JRD Tata, which gives insights into the life of great man and also presents another aspect of our 'demigod' leaders like Jawahar lal Nehru and Indira Gandhi. India : The Siege Within by M.J. AkbarVery skillfully explores the major issues which India is facing since independence, such as Kashmir issue, naxalism and others. Himalayan Blunder by Brigadier J. DalviA poignant tale by a Brigadier as to the real causes of defeat of India in Indo-China war of 1962. It was banned by Indian government soon after its launch. That should be a reason enough. The Shiva TrilogyGuess i need not say much on this. Although i did not liked the second and third part at all, the overall series carries a beautiful message : 'Excess of anything is bad, event if its elixir of life'

Palace of Illusions by Chitra Banerjee Divakaruni. The book stays with you long after you turn over the last page, and that in my opinion is the definition of a good book.Its the story of Mahabharata from the eyes of Draupadi. Now the story itself is timeless, but has never been told from the view point of the female protagonist. We all knew the details, but we didn't know her feelings, her desires, her pain, her agony, her secrets. All of it is revealed her and the author has done it in a way that leaves you astounded. A must read!

Indian fiction is such a vast corpus of significant works that to ask for a comprehensive list may not have an immediate use. Ponniyin Selvan by Kalki Krishnamoorthy. 5 volumes in total.    It is a historical fiction about how Rajaraja Chola, one of the greatest kings who walked on this planet, ascended the throne. Or did he? The story has extensive historical research and mentions, an intriguing plot, twists and turns, breath-taking characters and rich language. The books were written in Tamil but have been translated in many major languages. The books are still the best sellers in Tamil. Gems unknown outside Tamil speakers I'd say.

Always start with The Big Three of Indian Novels: Guide - R.K NarayanUntouchable  - Mulk Raj AnandThe serpent and the rope - Raja Rao Then you can try the following: Shadowlines - Amitav GhoshThe God of Small Things - Arundhati RoyMidnight Children - Salman RushdieThe White Tiger - Arvind Adiga All the above novels are widely popular all over the world...and if you do specilization in Indian English from any university in the world - you will end up reading almost all of them...

Balyakalasakhi - By Vaikom Mohammed Basheer I read a Tamil translation of this novel several years back. I remember having a lump in my throat when I put it down. I can only imagine what effect it would have on me if I were to ever read the original Malayalam version.I would say that God wrote via this man's pen. It is a simple story about childhood love. But it is also much much more. Right from the beginning, there is a sense of tragedy. But nothing prepares us for the final stab in the heart. Almost all great works ultimately acknowledge that life is absurd. This one does too. Sometimes you are happy and sometimes you suffer. There is no reason for either state. It just is.

Swami and friends... Swami and Friends is the first of a trilogy of novels written by RK Narayan , English language novelist from India. The novel, Narayan's first, is set in British India in a fictional town called Malgudi. The second and third books in the trilogy are The Bachelor of Arts and The English Teacher.Malgudi Schooldays is a slightly abridged version of Swami and Friends, and includes two additional stories featuring Swami from Malgudi Days and Under the Banyan Tree.       Its a story of a 10 year old boy Swami and his friends who have adventures in and out of the school. Swami has a whirpool of worries on his small world and this has been beautifully explained by the author. The characters are an inspiration from common people and the reader can easily co-relate them...

‘The God of Small Things’ by Arundhati Roy. Roy’s debut novel is a masterpiece. The book pivots around tragedy and hope. The book also explores the full range of human emotion. ‘The Inheritance of Loss’ by Kiran Desai. Despite the humor and wittiness encompassing it, The Inheritance of Loss remains a powerful book written with sheer honesty. The inner struggles of the characters could not be conveyed any better. Desai has the capacity to place the exact words on the most abstract feelings! The book is unflinchingly honest.

If you are into historical crime fiction, try "An Englishman's Cameo" by Madhulika Liddle. It was decent.

My Little India by Manoj Das.   Manoj Das is an Odia - English writer who has been a contributor since long. This book was originally written by him in Odia called "Antaranga Bharata" ( literally, Initimate India) as a collection of short stories of his travel across the country in the later part of 20th century. His works are so brilliant that they transfer you into another world where you need to close your eyes and picture the words written in the book. The Government of India has awarded him with the "Padma Shri", India's fourth highest civilian award for his contribution to literature. Also, another prestigious literary fellowship the "Sahitya Akademi Fellowship" which is highly regarded among Indian writers. I did not find a hard copy of the book, however the Amazon kindle store has a copy of the same. I loved the book! I'll name two because both are so different that I can't quite choose. The first is Midnight's Children by Salman Rushdie. The book is a partition novel and it provides some unique insight into the condition of the country at the time India was divided. The narration is from the perspective of a boy who is born at midnight on 15th August, 1947 and he has unique powers like the other children who were born between 12–1 am on 15th August. The book weaves in fantasy and reality seamlessly and you don't know when the real world events end and the fantasy begins. It's a very very good read and captured your imagination quite dexterously. The second is Palace Of Illusions by Chitra Banerjee Divakaruni. It's The Mahabharata from a woman's point of view and it is a phenomenonal piece of work. Draupadi, in this novel is not a passive pawn in the game played by the Men, she is an active participant and plays her own part with ferocity and determination.

The Gameworld Trilogy by Samit Basu.   Marketed as the first SFF (Science Fiction/Fantasy) book in India by an Indian Author, the Gameworld Trilogy is a sundry mix of satire,fantasy and alllegories. The world created by Samit Basu has esoteric creatures from Eastern and Western mythologies, blending together to make a fantastic read. On one hand you have the Vanars,Rakshasas and  Pashans while Dragons,Centaurs, Manticores and the alien Ravians are a good complement. The series is at once a subtle spoof and a classic fantasy racing through a world featuring characters and people from different cultures and mythologies.

A book that I’d recommend which I didn’t see in the answers is ’Em and The Big Hoom’ by Jerry Pinto.  It’s a wonderful book about a family living in a small 1 BHK apartment in Mahim, Bombay in the ‘80s. It’s a touching and engrossing story about how the children of the family cope with the mental illness of their mother throughout their childhood and adolescence and how they manage to be happy in spite of all the turmoil around them. I highly recommend this book, it’s awesome.

There are many books to mention, but I would like to mention the one I read recently. The book is titled The Man with Five Heads.  I would try to encompass what it offers in the following points: 1. Story: No spoilers here, though, I would like to tell that story is not a tribute, not an ode, nothing of the sort, but it is the story of creativity prior to the Neolithic Period (New Stone Age). The adrenaline rushing action sequences, poetic violence, comprehensive philosophy and the scientific definition of religion and God, are plain beauty. As John Keats said, it is a joy forever. 2. Language: I believe the language used in a book should be in synchronization with not just the story, but also the time frame of the story. Since the book is based on ancient Aryavart (India), the language used should have such beauty that it comes out as a character in its own. This book achieved that!! 3. Cover: The cover gives a sense of mysticism. Apt for the story. 4. Readability: The book is a page turner and leaves you wanting for more, in the end.

Parva by S.L. Bhyrappa Parva is a non-mythological retelling of the Mahabharata. Parva is written in the form of personal reflections of some of the principal characters of the epic.  Bhyrappa wrote the novel following a year-long research that covered multiple perspectives including the historicity of the Mahabharata, geography of India , anthropological aspects of the time, techniques of warfare, and philosophical concepts.  The novel was originally written in Kannada, but has been translated to English, Hindi and most other Indian languages. Best of Manto: a collection of short stories, Saddat Hassan Manto Saadat Hasan Manto, a writer born in undivided India, who died in Pakistan. Aavarana by S. L. Bhyrappa.  Originally written in kannada, later translated to Hindi Tamil and Marathi.  'Aavarana' literally means hiding/covering up of truth. It is about how the Indian history has been distorted for political reasons. Bhyrappa has witnessed the act of such distortion 1 - Distorting Indian History - S.L. Bhyrappa .   The book is strong and can be harsh, in the sense that it puts factual correctness well above political correctness. The author displays extensive research  on history, providing a long list of references at the end.  On a side note, the novel gives a great insight in to origin of religion and its role in the political organisation of human beings.

Books written by Indian authors in English have three problems:1. The dialogues and thoughts of the characters are "translated" from their native language to English and often sound absurd in that language.2. The writing mostly panders to a Western audience to whom the wonders of a poor, "native" and mysterious country are presented for awestruck consumption. The use of italicised Indian words like samosa, along with a footnote that explains what this is, underscores the nature of the target audience.3.  The experiences of the diaspora, especially in the US, have been done to death already.            I feel the best writing from India is in Indian languages, but there is a very limited readership for these which makes it commercially non-viable.             For the moment we have to suffer novels written as trilogies and sequels which get produced at the rate of one every six months or so by each gifted author!              Dickens and the Bard will surely be turning in their graves.

Hi Chandini. Well, there are plenty of Indian authors you would fall in love with.. Smart clichés are Ruskin Bond (if you love small towns, woods and hill stations), R.K. Narayan (if you believe simple delights in living, light humor, village lives, innocence) and Rabindranath Tagore (jack of all trades)... well (inappropriate advice) try to avoid Chetan Bhagat & Co. if you think Bollywood is stupid.

Manohar Malgonkar's "Bend in the Ganges" and "Spy in Amber" are two very interesting reads. An oft underrated author, Malgonkar writes with almost surgical precision and doesn't indulge in circumlocution, a trait that is shared by most of the Indian authors. R K Narayan's "The Financial Expert" is also a very interesting novel.
